Graphical abstract Three different alumina-supported catalysts were prepared according to 3 different methods, aiming at achieving fine deposition of gold particles. In methods 1 and 2, (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES) and (3-mercaptopropyl)triethoxysilane (MPTES) were respectively used as anchoring agents. In method 3, the gold particles were directly deposited on the support without using any anchoring agent. The performances of the so-obtained catalysts were evaluated in the reaction of glycerol partial oxidation in the liquid phase, and compared to those of a 1wt.% Au/Al2O3 catalyst provided by Mintek. The best catalyst A3 (method 3) exhibited a 99% conversion at 60̊C after 2.5h, with glyceric and glycolic acids selectivities of 60 and 20%, respectively. These performances were slightly higher than those of the reference commercial catalyst (95% conversion with glyceric and glycolic acids selectivities of 62 and 20%, respectively). In the case of A2 catalyst (method 2), in spite of very good dispersion of small nanoparticles on the surface, which is normally supposed to yield very active materials, a very strong inhibition of glycerol conversion was observed. After 2.5h of process at 60̊C, the glycerol conversion did not exceed 4%. A similar behavior was also observed for TiO2- and ZnO-supported catalysts, prepared in the same manner (using MPTES). In order to get a better understanding of the parameters ruling the reactivity of the various catalytic systems, a series of experiments over the commercial catalyst was performed, in which small quantities of various sulphur derivatives and antioxidants were used in the reaction mixture to simulate the response of the various species that can be present in the lab-prepared samples (method 2). The results, together with XPS analysis, suggests that there are three possible interpretations of the observed inhibition effect: (i) a strong interaction between gold and sulphur leading to the formation of covalent AuS bonds on nanoparticle's surface; (ii) the formation of so-called SAM's (self-assembled monolayers) blocking access to surface active centers; or (iii) an inhibition of the reactivity due to antioxidation properties of S-derivatives. Keywords Glycerol oxidation Supported gold catalyst Au–S interactions Inhibition by sulphur derivatives 1 Introduction Nowadays, it is believed that the glycerol can be a potentially important biorefinery feedstock [1,2], and its transformation by chemical or biochemical processes has thus attracted a lot of scientific attention in the last decades [1–5]. Oxidation in the liquid phase is an example of catalytic process that opens perspectives for converting glycerol to highly valuable products, such as glyceric acid, tartronic acid, glycolic acid, oxalic acid, dihydroxyacetone, or glyceraldehyde [1–4]. From the abundant literature, it appears that, so far, platinum, palladium, and especially gold-supported catalysts show very high activity in this process. It is also well known that their catalytic performances (and especially selectivity) are largely influenced by the preparation method and the selected reaction conditions [1,2,5–7]. Concerning gold-based catalysts, it is generally admitted that a proper selection of the support [8–10], of the gold precursor type [11], of the selected technique for particles deposition (impregnation, deposition–precipitation, use of an anchoring agent, etc.,) [1,7,12–14], as well as of the method and the conditions of the final steps of synthesis (drying and thermal or chemical reduction of the gold precursor [15–17]), has a significant influence on the properties of the final material. XPS (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy) and TEM (transmission electron microscopy) are largely used to reliably characterize such solids, as both techniques give complementary valuable information about the chemical state of gold (Au3+/Au0) and about the diameter of the deposited particles, respectively, which are key parameters governing the gold-based catalysts reactivity [1,5–7]. The results brought by elemental analysis are also of specific interest, since they straightforwardly enable the assessment of the actual amount of supported gold, which is an indicator of the preparation method efficiency, accuracy, and precision. Based on our previous experiences on finely controlled anchoring of gold nanoparticles in capillaries [18] and after examining the literature, especially the review of Daniel and Astruc [19] describing the formation of self-assembled monolayers (SAM's) and very well defined and arranged gold nanoparticles obtained using various derivatives, we selected and used APTES and MPTES as an anchoring agents for immobilization of reduced gold nanoparticles on an alumina surface. The third method used in this work was the direct deposition of the gold precursor on the alumina support followed by its chemical reduction in solution. The benefit of these methods is that they all allow the preparation of catalysts by a simplified “one-pot” procedure, which is thus an environmental friendly greener way and can have a large importance on the assessment of the catalysts competitiveness, especially referring to the commercial materials. In the present work, the AUROlite™ gold catalyst had been used as a reference, standard system (like already performed in several projects [20,21]), since it is considered as one of the most active materials. The main goal of our work was to compare usability of various anchoring agents for preparing fine gold-supported catalysts by simplified “one-pot” procedures, and testing their activity in the glycerol oxidation process. However, as our preliminary studies showed a strong inhibition of glycerol conversion while using catalysts prepared with MPTES, we decided to get deeper insights on this topic and present herein the possible explanations for this phenomena. According to the literature, very strong inhibition of the oxidation reaction over the catalysts prepared using MPTES as an anchoring agent could be explained by different hypotheses: (i) the thiol-based derivatives are known for their antioxidant activity in medicine, biochemistry, and oleochemistry [22–25], especially for the free-radical processes. On the other hand, (ii) it is well known that the basic conditions are preferable for glycerol oxidation over gold catalysts, so the acidic properties of SH groups present on the catalyst surface may attenuate the activation step expected by the base addition (here NaOH). Finally, (iii) the strong affinity between gold and sulphur resulting in a change in electronic properties of gold (covalent bond formation) enables formation of self-assembly 2D monolayers, the so-called SAM's, typical for thiolate compounds [26–29]. Evidences of such monolayers formation can be observed by XPS (shift of the BE of the Au 4f level [27]), and also by TEM (well-organized, symmetrical pattern with hexagonal distribution of surface immobilized AuNPs [30]). Thus, it is highly possible that the formation of a tight coverage of MPTES on the gold surface, which enables the formation of well-dispersed gold particles, can also block the access of reagents to the gold active centers. This aspect of selective site blocking by adsorbed thiolates was discussed in details by Haider et al., studying aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol and hydrogenation of ketopantolactone [31]. Also, Quantanilla et al. reported the effect of surface blocking by adsorption of weekly bounding capping agents (dodecylamine and PVP used in 10–35 molar excess to gold) [32], while Della Pina et al. working on gold-catalyzed aerobic oxidation of glucose pointed the alteration of the electronic properties of the gold by small amounts of thiol derivatives, as the main factor deciding about inhibition of the reaction [33]. Nevertheless, most of the works deal with the situation where the potential “poison” is added to the reaction mixture together with the reagents and standard gold supported catalyst. Herein, we compare the aforementioned hypothesis, and on the basis of a series of experiments we evaluate their impact on the glycerol oxidation reaction. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials used in the work All the chemicals were used as received without any further purification. Hydrogen tetrachloroaurate (III) trihydrate (HAuCl4) was purchased from Alfa Aesar, and sodium borohydride (NaBH4) 99% from Acros Organics. An alumina oxide powder (Al2O3) purchased from MERCK was used as a support, while APTES 99% from Aldrich and MPTES 99% purchased from Alfa Aesar were used as anchoring agents. Anhydrous glycerol 99% (C3H8O3) and purum sodium hydroxide (NaOH) from Sigma–Aldrich were used for the catalytic tests. The used eluent for liquid chromatography was prepared from HPLC-grade solvents: 0.25M H2SO4 from Fluka, deionized water and CH3CN from Sigma–Aldrich. All the solutions were prepared in distilled water (filter system: AUTOSTILL 4000X). The reference 1wt.% Au/Al2O3 catalyst (AUROlite™, batch BC17 labelled here K1) was received from Mintek, while 1wt.% Au/TiO2 and 1wt.% Au/ZnO (named here K2 and K3, respectively) were received from World Gold Council. Zinc oxide from Merck and titanium oxide from Degussa were used as a support for the preparation of Au/ZnO and Au/TiO2 series of catalysts. For supplementary tests in the presence of sulphur derivatives, we used (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane (MPTMS) from Aldrich, and thiophene as well as thioglycolic acid from Fluka. In the case of the use of antioxidants, we used the commonly employed butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT) and gallic acid from Aldrich. 2.2 Catalysts preparation methods All the catalysts were prepared by a simplified “one-pot” procedure. In the first method, APTES was used as an anchoring agent (method 1, catalyst A1): In a round-bottom flask, 1g of alumina support was suspended in 200cm3 of distilled water, and then APTES was added (molar ratio of APTES/Au= 2). The solution was then refluxed for 3h at 80̊C. Next, the gold precursor solution (HAuCl4) was added to the suspension in order to obtain the final catalyst with a total theoretical gold loading of 1wt.%. To achieve a pH value between 5 and 7, a sodium hydroxide solution was used. After 1h of continuous agitation and reflux at 80̊C, 1cm3 of reducing agent solution (containing 10mg of NaBH4) was added to the mixture, which resulted in an immediate change in color of the solution from yellow (characteristic for the gold precursor HAuCl4/Au3+) to dark brown, which gives a direct visual indication of the gold precursor reduction (Au3+ →Au0). The final mixture was maintained for an additional 2h under heating and mixing. Finally, the solid was filtrated on a Büchner funnel type 3, washed with 200cm3 of distilled water, and then dried in static air at 100̊C for 12h. In the second method, MPTES was used as an anchoring agent (method 2, catalyst A2), while in the third method (method 3, catalyst A3), no anchoring agent was used and the gold particles were directly deposited on the surface of the alumina support. Except this difference on anchoring agents, all the other preparation steps are identical to those described above for method 1. The same procedures were used for preparing gold supported on TiO2 and ZnO oxides, yielding respectively B1–B3 and C1–C3 series of catalysts. 2.3 Catalysts characterization The Au/alumina catalysts were observed using a “TEM FEI Tecnai G2-20 twin” electronic microscope, working with an accelerating potential of 200KV. Elemental chemical analyses of the catalysts were performed at the CNRS Central Analysis Service of Solaize by inductively coupled plasma - ICP (France). The XPS analyses were performed using a Kratos Analytical AXIS UltraDLD spectrometer. Monochromatized aluminum source (AlKα =1486.6eV) was used for excitation. The analyzer was operated in constant pass energy of 40eV using an analysis area of approximately 700μm×300μm. Charge compensation was applied to compensate for the charging effect occurring during the analysis. Quantification of the experimental photopeaks was carried out using the CasaXPS software taking into account a linear background subtraction. 2.4 Catalytic activity measurement A typical experiment of the liquid phase glycerol oxidation was carried out in a 300cm3 semi-batch stainless steel reactor equipped with a gas-induced turbine, 4 baffles, a thermocouple, a thermo-regulated oxygen supply system, and a pH probe. In each experiment, 200cm3 of glycerol solution in water was heated to the desired temperature (60̊C), and the reaction was started when the calculated amount of sodium hydroxide and the powdered gold catalyst were flushed through a specific fast introduction device into the reactor previously pressurized with oxygen (5bar) and placed under continuous stirring (1500rpm). In all the experiments, the initial concentration of glycerol was equal to 0.3M, and the amount of base was adjusted to give a NaOH/glycerol molar ratio of 4. The glycerol/gold molar ratio was fixed to 3500. For the supplementary studies, well-controlled quantities of selected sulphur-derivatives or antioxidants were introduced to the reactor together with the reagents. The temperature, pH, and O2 pressure were continuously monitored, while the reaction mixture was periodically sampled (1cm3 samples directly acidified to quench the reaction). The products were analyzed with an Agilent 1200 HPLC equipped with a Rezex ROA-Organic Acid H+ column (300×7.8mm) and a reflective index detector (RID). A solution of H2SO4 (0.0024M) and CH3CN (0.0001M) in deionized water (0.48cm3 min−1) was used as an eluent. The identification and quantification of the obtained products were done by comparison with the corresponding calibration curves. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization First, XPS analysis was performed in order to confirm the oxidation state of the anchored gold particles and to evaluate the atomic amount of gold (Au3+ or Au0) present in the first few nanometers of the catalysts’ surface (Fig. 1 ). For all the samples, including the commercial AUROlite™ catalyst (labelled as K1), the Au 4f7/2 photoelectron peak binding energy (BE) varied in the 84.0±0.3eV range, as reported in Table 1 , which is characteristic of metallic Au0 species [34]. The binding energy of the Au 4f level is very sensitive to the gold surrounding chemical environment [35]. The shift in the BE values over gold catalysts has been usually attributed to: (i) electron transfer from the support to the Au particles [36,37], (ii) change in the size and shape of the gold clusters on the support surface [37], or (iii) incomplete reduction of the deposited gold clusters [38]. The shift of BE of the Au 4f7/2 level observed for A1 and A2 catalysts compared to the A3 and K1 catalysts (+0.2eV and +0.5eV, respectively) can be explained by strong interaction between the used anchoring agents and the generated gold particles [36]. In the case of the A1 catalyst with basic amine groups originating from APTES, and A3 prepared by adsorption of gold nanoparticles on an unmodified alumina support, the position of the Au 4f7/2 level (84.0 and 83.8eV, respectively), and the amount of gold (0.3 and 0.2at.%, respectively) detected by XPS are quite similar. In both cases, the gold particles are attached to the support by electrostatic forces [39]. These observations are consistent with the larger shift in BE for the A2 sample, where MPTES was used as an anchoring agent and the system should end up with a partially covalent bond between the gold and the acidic thiol groups (SH) [19,36]. Similar conclusion was found by Bourg et al. [27], who investigated gold–sulphur bonding in 2D and 3D SAM's using XPS technique. The authors found that the peak at 84.3eV should be prominent in the case of spherical nanoparticles with about 2.8nm diameter, in which all the surface atoms (about 48% of all atoms in the nanoparticle) would be involved in the AuS bond. Formation of covalent AuS bond and strong interactions between both atoms has been also discussed elsewhere [26,28,40]. The theoretical total amount of gold was 1wt.% for all the prepared catalysts (A1, A2, and A3). However, the elemental analysis showed in each case a total gold loading of 0.85wt.% (Table 1). These results mean that only 15% of the originally anchored gold was lost during the novel “one-pot” synthesis method we propose. This amount is lower than that observed for the same type of support while using conventional adsorption–deposition procedure, where more than 25% of gold can be lost during the preparation step [41,42]. The differences in the surface loading found by XPS analysis (Table 1) can be explained in the light of the catalyst surface morphology and the nature of the chemicals used in the preparation methods. XPS technique is a surface analysis, where about 10nm of the depth of the catalyst surface can be analyzed. Thus, the particles located in the support pores might not be detected. This is the same – at least partially – for particles surrounded by polymer-type coating (anchoring agent). The works of Li et al. [35], Liu et al. [43], and also Smith and Chen [44] show that the anchoring agents used in this work (mainly APTES) are able to polymerize, especially in the presence of water, forming a number of possible 2D and 3D surface structures [39]. Hence, thin submonolayer coverage can be formed by simple covalent and/or electrostatic interactions. 2D monolayers with possible square planar or hexagonal arrangement of the surface-immobilized nanoparticles are created by horizontal polymerization [45], while vertical polymerization enables appearance of 3D multilayer (Fig. 2 ) [39]. Thus, the gold particles surrounded by polymerized anchoring agent (used in excess) can be easily trapped inside the film enveloping the support surface. The thickness of such film is related to the nature of the chemicals and the conditions used during the synthesis [44], and for the monolayer coverage it has been evaluated at around 0.9nm for APTES [44,46] and 0.8–0.9nm for MPTES [47]. Thus, for conditions used in this work (1wt.% Au, gold/anchoring agent molar ratio 1) no significant attenuation of XPS signal should be observed. However, the data presented in Table 1 show that the amount of gold detected on the surface of the A2 catalyst is much more important (1.1at.%) than that on the other two catalysts, where the surface gold content is estimated at 0.25±0.05at.%. As the bulk gold loading estimated by elemental analysis (ICP) is comparable for all the catalysts, this can indicate the presence of very small and homogenously dispersed gold nanoparticles on the A2 catalyst support surface. Indeed, the TEM analysis performed to determine the gold particles diameter supported on alumina (Fig. 3 ) proved that the average particle size was indeed different for A2 compared with A1, A3 and also for the commercial K1 catalyst (the average particle size of each catalyst was obtained by measuring about 200 nanoparticles over multiple areas). For the A1 catalyst, the average diameter of the anchored particles was 3.4nm, which was close to the results over the A3 catalyst (3.6nm), for which no anchoring agent was used, and to the commercial K1 catalyst with average diameter of 3.2nm. On the other hand, the gold particles deposited on the A2 catalyst surface showed a much smaller diameter with a narrow size distribution: almost 80% of the particles had a diameter ≤2nm (average value was estimated at 2.0nm). This decrease in the gold particle diameter in the case of the A2 catalyst can again be explained by the presence of thiol groups, which are considered as excellent stabilizers due to the formation of strong AuS bond [19,26,28]. Such enhanced interaction (already pointed out by XPS results) enables isolation of very small gold nanoparticles, which is not observed when using weakly binding stabilizers such as amine-derivatives and/or polymers [45]. 3.2 Catalytic performances The catalytic performance of the prepared materials was assessed in the glycerol oxidation reaction in the liquid phase. A clear relation between the average diameter of the gold nanoparticles and their reactivity might be observed, as described elsewhere [1]. However, the chemical nature of the anchoring agent can also play a role. For example APTES amine groups could be a potential basic center on the catalyst surface, while thiol from MPTES an acidic one. Obviously, the presence of the aforementioned components may have an influence on the final catalyst activity. However, such effect has not been reported so far in the literature. The catalytic tests results over the alumina-supported series of catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . After 2.5h of oxidation process, the highest glycerol conversion (almost 100%) was obtained over the A3 catalyst, prepared without using any anchoring agent. This catalyst was slightly more active than the reference commercial catalyst (K1), as the initial conversion rate was 0.381moldm–3 h–1 for A3 vs., 0.342moldm–3 h–1 for K1. The use of APTES (A1) gave a slightly less active catalyst, with a glycerol conversion of 84.3% after 2.5h of test at 60̊C and an initial conversion rate of 0.208moldm–3 h–1. In contrast, low catalytic activity was observed when using the A2 catalyst. As the maximum glycerol conversion after 2.5h of test was lower than 5%, we did not include the selectivity of this material in the comparison of the main products distribution, calculated for 40% of glycerol conversion (Fig. 4b). Nevertheless, similarly to the other Au/Al2O3 materials, the major products detected for A2 catalyst were glyceric, glycolic, and formic acids, with selectivities of 42, 37, and 19%, respectively. A very small amount of tartronic acid was also detected in the reaction mixture. For A1, A3, and K1 catalysts the selectivities to glyceric, glycolic, and formic acids, the major reaction products, were estimated at 60–61, 19–20, and 13–14% in each case. Also, the distribution of less important products, such as oxalic and tartronic acids, was comparable (about 1.5 and 3–5%, respectively). The only difference was in the glyoxylic acid formation, which was detected only at very high glycerol conversion (above 80%) over the A3 catalyst, but not over both A1 and K1 catalysts. From the physicochemical point of view, these three catalysts are quite similar, i.e., in each case the total amount of gold is 0.84–0.85wt.%, and also the diameter of the gold nanoparticles is very similar (3.2–3.6nm). The only small difference concerns the amount of gold present at the supports’ surface determined by the XPS technique (Table 1). Almost identical trends were also observed for the B and C series of the catalysts, where, respectively, titanium oxide and zinc oxide were used as supports for gold nanoparticles. As it can be seen from Fig. 5 , and irrespective of the type of support, using MPTES as an anchoring agent resulted in strong inhibition of glycerol conversion. In both cases, the final glycerol conversion after 2h at 60̊C was below 2%, i.e., 1.8% for TiO2-supported catalyst (B2) and 1.6% for the ZnO-based material (C2). However, the most interesting result is obtained from the comparison of these results with the blank test, where 8.4% of glycerol conversion could be obtained after 2h of tests carried out under analogous reaction conditions without the presence of gold catalyst (results of so-called “blank tests” reported elsewhere [48]). 3.3 Effect of sulphur compounds As mentioned in the introduction, there are three possible interpretations of the observed inhibition effect: (i) an inhibition of the catalyst reactivity due to antioxidation properties of S-derivatives; (ii) attenuation of the activation step by acidic properties of SH groups present on the catalyst surface; or (iii) a strong interaction between gold and sulphur leading to the formation of covalent AuS bonds on the nanoparticle's surface, which result in the formation of the so-called SAM's (self-assembled monolayers) blocking access to the surface active centers. To assess the aforementioned hypotheses, additional experiments were carried out using commercial K1 catalyst and a well-determined quantity of, respectively: (a) amine and thiol-based anchoring agents, namely: (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane and (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane; (b) selected sulphur derivatives as thiophene and thioglycolic acid; and finally (c) commonly used commercial antioxidants, like butylated hydroxytoluene and gallic acid. The results are shown in Table 2 . 3.3.1 Antioxidation properties According to the first hypothesis (i) 0.02mmol of (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane introduced in the reaction mixture containing the commercial K1 catalyst (test no. 3) caused very strong decrease in the glycerol conversion to 3.8%. The amount of thiol derivative was adjusted to give the same theoretical S/Au molar ratio in the reaction mixture as in A2 catalyst, and in this case the effect on glycerol conversion was substantially the same (test no. 2 vs., test no. 3). On the other hand, addition of the same amount (0.02mmol) of common antioxidant like butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT known as a food additive with E 321 symbol) only slightly affected the glycerol conversion, although its concentration was 10 or 100 times higher than that of sulphur derivative (tests no. 5 and 6 vs., test no. 4 in Table 2). Relatively strong inhibition of the oxidation process over commercial Au/Al2O3 catalyst was observed only when a very high amount of antioxidant was used (test no. 7). Here, because of the poor solubility of BHT in the reaction mixture, we have chosen another popular antioxidant, i.e., gallic acid, of which the ethyl ester is known as E 313. Even if the molar ratio of glycerol to gallic acid was equal to 1, the conversion remained relatively high in comparison to the test with A2 catalyst (24.8% vs., 2.6%). As this less important effect of commercial antioxidants might be caused by their weaker antioxidizing properties in comparison to the thiol derivative, we decided to carry out oxidation tests without using gold catalyst, in order to get rid of the possibility of any additional effect related with AuS interactions. Because the conversion of glycerol after 1h of test at 60̊C without gold catalyst and with a NaOH/glycerol molar ratio of 4 hardly reached 5% [48], we chose the relatively high reaction temperature of 100̊C. After 2h under such conditions, almost 90% of glycerol conversion could be reached (test no. 10), this value being close to the result observed over our reference test, i.e., after 1h at 60̊C over the commercial gold catalyst (test no. 1). Analogous test performed with (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane (0.02mmol) and BHT (0.20mmol) proved that both components affect glycerol conversion in very similar way (tests 11 and 12), decreasing it to 26–27%. This confirms that thiol-derivative is about 10 times more powerful as an antioxidant (inhibitor) than BHT, but this ability is not the only factor responsible that can explain absolute inhibition of the glycerol conversion over gold catalyst. 3.3.2 Effect of functional group acidity Discussing the second possible hypothesis (ii) it should be underlined that in each test the initial molar ratio of sodium hydroxide to glycerol was fixed at value 4, which resulted in an overall pH of the reaction mixture varying during the oxidation processes between 12.4 and 12.3, even in the case of very high glycerol conversion, like for the K1 catalyst (Table 2, no. 1). Moreover, the same pH range was also observed for the tests with small quantities of thiol and amine anchoring agents introduced in the reactor together with glycerol, sodium hydroxide, and commercial K1 material (Table 2, tests 3, and 4, respectively). As the conversion of glycerol in the presence of APTES almost did not vary from that obtained during the reference test without any additive (entry 1), this suggests that the effect of the acidity of SH groups cannot be taken as responsible for the strong inhibition of glycerol conversion, which is observed both in the presence of (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane, as well as during the tests with the catalysts prepared by method 2, where the conversion did not pass 4%. Another conclusion, which arises from this test, is that the silane group present in (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane and (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane is not affecting the oxidation process. 3.3.3 Formation of SAM's The last possible explanation (iii) is related with the strong AuS interaction potentially leading to the formation of a tight coverage, blocking the access of reagents to the catalyst surface. From the literature, it is known that sulphur derivatives, and especially thiolates, are one of the most effective components enabling the formation of SAMs on gold surfaces [19,26–29,49]. The formation rate of such monolayers depends not only on the proper choice of the deposition conditions (i.e., the type of the solvent, the concentration and the temperature), but also on the chemical character of the used component, namely, the type of sulphur-functional group (SH, S orSS), as well as on the number of C-atoms in the organic part of the component, on the aliphatic or aromatic character, on the degree of branching, on the presence of other functional groups, etc., [19]. Generally, aliphatic thiols are considered as the most powerful agents in SAM's formation [19,27]. In our work we tested three different sulphur derivatives: thiophene, thioglycolic acid, and (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane. The total concentration of each component in the reaction mixture was adjusted between 7–19ppm, which gave a nominal S/Au molar ratio of 1. As aforementioned, the same molar ratio was used during the preparation of supported catalyst by method 2, i.e., when using MPTES as an anchoring agent. XPS analysis showed that the real atomic ratio between sulphur and gold on the fresh A2 catalyst was 0.78, while the measurement performed after glycerol oxidation reaction showed almost the same value of 0.77. Moreover, the Au/Al atomic ratio also remained almost unchanged, i.e., 0.034 vs., 0.033. That confirmed the deposition of very stable gold nanoparticles on MPTES-treated alumina via strong AuS bonding. As it is shown in Table 2 (tests no. 3, 8, and 9), the glycerol conversion in each test with S-derivatives was much lower in comparison to the other experiments with APTES and antioxidants. The strongest inhibition was observed during the oxidation reaction with 0.02mmol of thioglycolic acid. In that case, the glycerol conversion was only 2.6%, the same as that over the A2 catalyst, while using 0.02mmol of (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane yielded in 3.8% conversion. Less important inhibition effect of thiophene addition (S functional group) can be explained by its lower rate of adsorption on the gold surface in comparison to SH derivatives [49]. In order to perform reliable XPS analysis of used sample, the K1 catalyst recovered after the experiment with 0.02mmol of (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane (Table 2, test no. 3) was washed with 200cm3 of distilled water and dried 24h at 110̊C. Although sulphur signal was not detected, the concentration of gold, as well as the Au/Al atomic ratio, remained the same as in the fresh K1 catalyst (0.1and 0.002at.%, respectively). Thus, blocking the access of reagents to the catalyst surface seems to be an important factor deciding about deep inhibition of the glycerol oxidation reaction. 4 Conclusion The results presented in this paper evidence a close relation between the chemical properties of the anchoring agent used for gold deposition and the performances of the finally so-obtained catalysts. This effect was very clear, especially with MPTES, where a strong decrease in glycerol conversion was observed (Fig. 4a). In such case, the conversion after 2.5h of oxidation process at 60̊C was below 5%, which is even less than the result obtained in the presence of a base alone, i.e., in the absence of any metallic catalyst (conversion of glycerol in the reference blank test was close to 8%) [39]. This study constitutes an important approach to understand clearly the effect of the thiolate-based chemicals on the gold catalysts in the liquid phase glycerol oxidation reaction. On the basis of series of experiments we can assume that there are two effects, coexisting together and affecting the overall glycerol conversion: (i) the antioxidant properties of SH moieties present on the catalysts’ surface confirmed by tests with antioxidants; (ii) the strong AuS interaction leading to the formation of very well dispersed small Au nanoparticles on the support surface, which are supposed to have a beneficial effect in the terms of catalytic activity and glycerol conversion, but, on the other side, it induces the formation of a tight organic coverage over the catalysts, which is responsible for a blocking of the access of reagents to the catalyst surface. coredata.dc:description: Three different alumina-supported catalysts were prepared according to 3 different methods, aiming at achieving fine deposition of gold particles. In methods 1 and 2, (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES) and (3-mercaptopropyl)triethoxysilane (MPTES) were respectively used as anchoring agents. In method 3, the gold particles were directly deposited on the support without using any anchoring agent. The performances of the so-obtained catalysts were evaluated in the reaction of glycerol partial oxidation in the liquid phase, and compared to those of a 1wt.% Au/Al2O3 catalyst provided by Mintek. The best catalyst A3 (method 3) exhibited a 99% conversion at 60̊C after 2.5h, with glyceric and glycolic acids selectivities of 60 and 20%, respectively. These performances were slightly higher than those of the reference commercial catalyst (95% conversion with glyceric and glycolic acids selectivities of 62 and 20%, respectively). In the case of A2 catalyst (method 2), in spite of very good dispersion of small nanoparticles on the surface, which is normally supposed to yield very active materials, a very strong inhibition of glycerol conversion was observed. After 2.5h of process at 60̊C, the glycerol conversion did not exceed 4%. A similar behavior was also observed for TiO2- and ZnO-supported catalysts, prepared in the same manner (using MPTES). In order to get a better understanding of the parameters ruling the reactivity of the various catalytic systems, a series of experiments over the commercial catalyst was performed, in which small quantities of various sulphur derivatives and antioxidants were used in the reaction mixture to simulate the response of the various species that can be present in the lab-prepared samples (method 2). The results, together with XPS analysis, suggests that there are three possible interpretations of the observed inhibition effect: (i) a strong interaction between gold and sulphur leading to the formation of covalent AuS bonds on nanoparticle's surface; (ii) the formation of so-called SAM's (self-assembled monolayers) blocking access to surface active centers; or (iii) an inhibition of the reactivity due to antioxidation properties of S-derivatives.
coredata.dc:title: Glycerol oxidation over gold supported catalysts – “Two faces” of sulphur based anchoring agent
